          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');
        </script><head><meta charSet="utf-8"/><meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width"/><link rel="shortcut icon" href="https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/favicon.7bc3d920.ico"/><script>

          name: "page_rendering",

          value: JSON.stringify({
            time: performance?.now()
          })
        })
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Failed to push page render event:", error)

class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">The document presents a comprehensive analysis of targeted credential phishing threats over the past decade, detailing the evolution of attack methods and defenses. It highlights crucial developments like SMS interception, two-factor authentication vulnerabilities, and the importance of security keys and OAuth. The report outlines various actors involved in these attacks and suggests enhanced protective measures to combat ongoing threats.</p><div class="pills-list PillsList_root__2EydN"><a style="anchor-name:--popover-R7ap7d6"><span class="SlidePreviews_slideHeading__sTrgx slide-heading">53</span><div class="SlidePreviews_thumbnailContainer__QWeuK thumbnail-container" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405"><div class="SlidePreviews_thumbnail__6RNF6" class="" id=":R7ap7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7ap7d6"></div></div><div class="SlidePreviews_previewContainer__Qn8CH"><a aria-describedby="key-moment-53" class="SlidePreviews_momentContainer__zhQyW" href="#54" id="slide-preview-53" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7cp7d6:" popovertarget=":R7cp7d6:" class="vertical-player VerticalPlayer_root__K8_YS" data-slideshow-id="83684578"><div><div id="slide1" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-0" alt="Threat Analysis Group
November 2017 - @billyleonard
10 Years of Targeted Credential Phishing
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="high" loading="eager" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-1-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-1-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-1-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-1-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide2" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-1" alt="Threat Analysis Group
Billy Leonard
Threat Analysis Group
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-2-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-2-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-2-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-2-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide3" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-2" alt="Threat Analysis Group
But first, ….
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-3-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-3-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-3-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-3-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide4" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-3" alt="Threat Analysis Group
What we don&#x27;t see in targeted phishing.
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="Threat Analysis Group
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-5-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-5-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-5-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-5-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide6" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-5" alt="Threat Analysis Group
Targeted attacks are all really advanced.

The Early Days.

The Middle Ages.

Advanced Protection Program

SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the WannaCry ransomware attack in May 2017. It began by exploiting a vulnerability in Microsoft SMBv1 protocol using NSA hacking tools leaked online. WannaCry encrypted files on Windows computers in over 150 countries, demanding $300 ransom payments in Bitcoin. Key lessons are the attack demonstrated the risks of not applying software patches and the new era of ransomware using worms to spread rapidly across networks. Proactive prevention measures like backups and secure network segmentation are discussed.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R13lh7d6:" popovertarget=":R13lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R13lh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SecureAuth2FASSO/webinar-goodbye-rsa-hello-modern-authentication"><span class="sr-only">Webinar: Goodbye RSA. SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">1. The document discusses the misuse of stolen credentials and the need to go beyond standard two-factor authentication. 
2. It provides examples of how two-factor authentication can fail, such as through SMS interception, social engineering of knowledge-based authentication questions, and users wrongly accepting authentication requests.  
3. The document promotes an adaptive authentication approach using multiple layers of risk analysis and a wide range of authentication methods to strengthen security with minimal user impact.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Mobile User Authentication Challenge</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Taking Control of the Digital and Mobile User Authentication Challenge for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfd5lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfd5lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rfd5lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfd5lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfd5lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/emcacademics">EMC</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the growing challenges in digital and mobile user authentication caused by increasing numbers of websites and user accounts, leading to password proliferation and security vulnerabilities. It highlights the need for enterprises to develop more sophisticated authentication strategies, as traditional methods are often inadequate and risky in the evolving landscape that includes mobile and cloud technologies. The text explores various solutions and case studies aimed at improving security while balancing user convenience and operational efficiency.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15lh7d6:" in technology, including a lack of empathy and diversity in teams, an overvaluation of complexity, and misaligned incentives that prioritize growth and headlines over minimizing real-world harm. Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document outlines the security architecture of the Xbox One, emphasizing the necessity for custom silicon to resist physical attacks and piracy. Key strategies include a dedicated security processor, layered defenses, and enforcing strict code execution policies, which ensure that malicious code cannot persist after a reboot. The approach taken by Xbox differs significantly from traditional Windows security measures, as it must account for the console owner potentially being an attacker.</span></div></div><div class="" intermediate representations (IR) in reverse engineering and compiler design. class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the findings of Veracode&#x27;s 10th annual State of Software Security report. The report is based on scan data from over 85,000 applications assessed between April 2018 and March 2019. Key findings include: (1) Most security flaws are eventually fixed but fix times have remained consistent, (2) The likelihood of flaws being fixed decreases over time leading to growing &quot;security debt&quot;, (3) Frequent scanning correlated with faster fix times and lower security debt indicating the benefits of DevSecOps practices. The data suggests security testing automation still lags DevOps adoption and developers prioritize recent flaws over severity.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jlh7d6:" popover="auto" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document outlines the challenges and security patterns involved in building secure machine learning pipelines at LinkedIn, detailing various use cases and phases within ML pipelines. It highlights primary security concerns, such as unauthorized access, data leakage, and vulnerabilities throughout different phases of model training, deployment, and inference, while proposing several security controls and patterns. Key takeaways focus on the importance of segregating infrastructure and employing continuous monitoring, efficient identity management, and automation of security controls.</span></div></div><div Let&#x27;s try to do better fuzzing for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfdmlh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfdmlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rfdmlh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfdmlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfdmlh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the internals of syzkaller, an in-kernel fuzzer for finding bugs. It explains that syzkaller sprays large allocations across memory pages to leave small holes, then sprays the targeted object to fill one of the holes and have the target in front of the spray. This allows the target object to be found and used for exploitation. It also provides statistics on the types of bugs found by syzkaller, with most being exploitable bugs or crashes/stability issues found through fuzzing kernel interfaces.</span></div></div><div It also outlines trends in the market, such as the impact of new mitigations, regulations, and events like Pwn2Own on the sale of exploits. Finally, it shares some examples of vulnerabilities the Zero Day Initiative has helped patch and the conclusion encourages questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1rlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1rlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-27" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1slh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1slh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1slh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-v18-the-matrix-has-you-protecting-linux-using-deception/119144744"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - protecting linux using deception</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:27" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - It highlights various types of honeypots, including traditional and hybrid models, and their role in tracking and analyzing attacks. Additionally, it emphasizes the importance of data analytics, the complexities of SSH protocols, and the need for effective simulations to defend against both skilled and amateur Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses some fundamental problems in technology, including a lack of empathy and diversity in teams, an overvaluation of complexity, and misaligned incentives that prioritize growth and headlines over minimizing real-world harm. It argues that technology companies have not been proactively honest about downsides and have failed to learn from past mistakes. Some recommendations are made, including emphasizing empathy and diversity to better predict harm, shifting risk ownership, adjusting incentives away from complexity and towards harm prevention, and teaching these lessons in computer science education.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R8j5i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document outlines the security architecture of the Xbox One, emphasizing the necessity for custom silicon to resist physical attacks and piracy. Key strategies include a dedicated security processor, layered defenses, and enforcing strict code execution policies, which ensure that malicious code cannot persist after a reboot. The approach taken by Xbox differs significantly from traditional Windows security measures, as it must account for the console owner potentially being an attacker.</span></div></div><div class="" nodes. GitHub, focuses on securing the open source landscape, particularly in C/C++ and Golang, and addresses challenges such as code quality and supply chain vulnerabilities. The document discusses various strategies and tools for vulnerability discovery, including continuous fuzzing services and data flow analysis using a specific query language, QL, for identifying issues like integer overflows. It also highlights the impact of contributions from Google and other organizations on uncovering and addressing vulnerabilities in open source software.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R9b5i7d6:" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses modern binary analysis and the role of intermediate languages (IL) and intermediate representations (IR) in reverse engineering and compiler design. It emphasizes the challenges of static binary analysis, the complexities introduced by compilers, and the advantages of using ILs for more efficient and reliable analysis. Additionally, it provides an overview of various IL projects and their characteristics, highlighting tradeoffs between verbosity and conciseness in instruction sets.</span></div></div><div class="" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the findings of Veracode&#x27;s 10th annual State of Software Security report. The report is based on scan data from over 85,000 applications assessed between April 2018 and March 2019. Key findings include: (1) Most security flaws are eventually fixed but fix times have remained consistent, (2) The likelihood of flaws being fixed decreases over time leading to growing &quot;security debt&quot;, (3) Frequent scanning correlated with faster fix times and lower security debt indicating the benefits of DevSecOps practices. The data suggests security testing automation still lags DevOps adoption and developers prioritize recent flaws over severity.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rar5i7d6:" popover="auto" Let&#x27;s try to do better fuzzing for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3rbj5i7d6:" popovertarget=":R3rbj5i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3rbj5i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R3rbj5i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3rbj5i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the internals of syzkaller, an in-kernel fuzzer for finding bugs. It explains that syzkaller sprays large allocations across memory pages to leave small holes, then sprays the targeted object to fill one of the holes and have the target in front of the spray. This allows the target object to be found and used for exploitation. It also provides statistics on the types of bugs found by syzkaller, with most being exploitable bugs or crashes/stability issues found through fuzzing kernel interfaces.</span></div></div><div It describes how vulnerabilities are found by researchers and sold through brokers to various parties, including governments, criminals, and exploit kit creators. It also outlines trends in the market, such as the impact of new mitigations, regulations, and events like Pwn2Own on the sale of exploits. Finally, it shares some examples of vulnerabilities the Zero Day Initiative has helped patch and the conclusion encourages questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rcr5i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rcr5i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-19" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rd35i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rd35i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rd35i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-v18-the-matrix-has-you-protecting-linux-using-deception/119144744"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - protecting linux using deception</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:19" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - protecting linux using deception</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - protecting linux using deception for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3rd35i7d6:" popovertarget=":R3rd35i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3rd35i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R3rd35i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3rd35i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the use of deception technologies in cybersecurity to better understand attackers and their methods. It highlights various types of honeypots, including traditional and hybrid models, and their role in tracking and analyzing attacks. Additionally, it emphasizes the importance of data analytics, the complexities of SSH protocols, and the need for effective simulations to defend against both skilled and amateur attackers.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rd35i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rd35i7d6"></div></div><div class="desktop-recs"><div class="Slider_root__c0Jo8"><div class="Slider_scroller__KHjw4"><div class="BottomRecommendationCard_root__gffTk SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-seattle-2019-the-cake-is-a-lie-uncovering-the-secret-world-of-malwarelike-cheats-in-video-games/201112400"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat Seattle 2019 || The cake is a lie! Quality Management: aka One man&#x27;s love for the...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-cy="slideshow-title">Using the SQLExecutor for Data Quality Management: aka One man&#x27;s love for the...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Using the SQLExecutor for Data Quality Management: aka One man&#x27;s love for the... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3r936i7d6:" popovertarget=":R3r936i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3r936i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R3r936i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3r936i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SafeSoftware">Safe Software</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The SQLExecutor is one of FME’s most powerful and flexible transformers. Pivvot maintains a robust internal metadata hierarchy used to support ingestion and curation of thousands of external data sources that must be managed for quality before entering our platform. By using the SQLExecutor, Pivvot can efficiently detect problems and perform analysis before data is extracted from our staging environment, removing the need for rollbacks or cycles waisted on a failed job. This presentation will walk through three distinct examples of how Pivvot uses the SQLExecutor to engage its metadata hierarchy and integrate with its Data Quality Management workflows efficiently and within the source postgres database. Spatial Validation –Validating spatial prerequisites before entering a production environment. Reference Data Validation - Dynamically validate domain-ed columns across any table and multiple columns per table. Practical De-duplication - Removing identical or near-identical well point locations from two distinct source datasets in the same table.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R936i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R936i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R9b6i7d6:" popovertarget=":R9b6i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R9b6i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/you-are-not-excused-how-to-avoid-security-blind-spots-on-the-way-to-production/280604626"><span class="sr-only">You are not excused! How to avoid security blind spots on the way to production</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">You are not excused! How to avoid security blind spots on the way to production</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save You are not excused! How to avoid security blind spots on the way to production for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3r9b6i7d6:" popovertarget=":R3r9b6i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3r9b6i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R3r9b6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3r9b6i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/michelebusta">Michele Leroux Bustamante</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">We live in an ever evolving landscape for cyber threats creating security risk for your production systems. Mitigating these risks requires participation throughout all stages from development through production delivery - and by every role including architects, developers QA and DevOps engineers, product owners and leadership. No one is excused! This session will cover examples of common mistakes or missed opportunities that can lead to vulnerabilities in production - and ways to do better throughout the development lifecycle.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R9b6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R9b6i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-5" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R9j6i7d6:" popovertarget=":R9j6i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R9j6i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/smarter-aviation-data-management-lessons-from-swedavia-airports-and-sweco/280714317"><span class="sr-only">Smarter Aviation Data Management: Lessons from Swedavia Airports and Sweco</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Smarter Aviation Data Management: Lessons from Swedavia Airports and Sweco</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Smarter Aviation Data Management: Lessons from Swedavia Airports and Sweco for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3r9j6i7d6:" popovertarget=":R3r9j6i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3r9j6i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R3r9j6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3r9j6i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SafeSoftware">Safe Software</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Managing airport and airspace data is no small task, especially when you’re expected to deliver it in AIXM format without spending a fortune on specialized tools. But what if there was a smarter, more affordable way?

Join us for a behind-the-scenes look at how Sweco partnered with Swedavia, the Swedish airport operator, to solve this challenge using FME and Esri.

Learn how they built automated workflows to manage periodic updates, merge airspace data, and support data extracts – all while meeting strict government reporting requirements to the Civil Aviation Administration of Sweden.

Even better? Swedavia built custom services and applications that use the FME Flow REST API to trigger jobs and retrieve results – streamlining tasks like securing the quality of new surveyor data, creating permdelta and baseline representations in the AIS schema, and generating AIXM extracts from their AIS data.

To conclude, FME expert Dean Hintz will walk through a GeoBorders reading workflow and highlight recent enhancements to FME’s AIXM (Aeronautical Information Exchange Model) processing and interpretation capabilities.

Discover how airports like Swedavia are harnessing the power of FME to simplify aviation data management, and how you can too.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R9j6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R9j6i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R9r6i7d6:" popovertarget=":R9r6i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R9r6i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/pycon-sg-25-firecracker-made-easy-with-python-pdf/280700335"><span class="sr-only">PyCon SG 25 - class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R3raj6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3raj6i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/biswajitbanerjee38">biswajitbanerjee38</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Russia is one of the most aggressive nations when it comes to state coordinated cyberattacks — and Ukraine has been at the center of their crosshairs for 3 years. This report, provided the State Service of Special Communications and Information Protection of Ukraine contains an incredible amount of cybersecurity insights, showcasing the coordinated aggressive cyberwarfare campaigns of Russia against Ukraine.

It brings to the forefront that understanding your adversary, especially an aggressive nation state, is important for cyber defense. Knowing their motivations, capabilities, and tactics becomes an advantage when allocating resources for maximum impact.

Intelligence shows Russia is on a cyber rampage, leveraging FSB, SVR, and GRU resources to professionally target Ukraine’s critical infrastructures, military, and international diplomacy support efforts.

The number of total incidents against Ukraine, originating from Russia, has steadily increased from 1350 in 2021 to 4315 in 2024, but the number of actual critical incidents has been managed down from a high of 1048 in 2022 to a mere 59 in 2024 — showcasing how the rapid detection and response to cyberattacks has been impacted by Ukraine’s improved cyber resilience.

Even against a much larger adversary, Ukraine is showcasing outstanding cybersecurity, enabled by strong strategies and sound tactics. There are lessons to learn for any enterprise that could potentially be targeted by aggressive nation states.

Definitely worth the read!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Raj6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Raj6i7d6"></div><div class="separator class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">From Manual to Auto Searching- FME in the Driver&#x27;s Seat</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save From Manual to Auto Searching- FME in the Driver&#x27;s Seat for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3rbj6i7d6:" popovertarget=":R3rbj6i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3rbj6i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R3rbj6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3rbj6i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SafeSoftware">Safe Software</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Finding a specific car online can be a time-consuming task, especially when checking multiple dealer websites. A few years ago, I faced this exact problem while searching for a particular vehicle in New Zealand. The local classified platform, Trade Me (similar to eBay), wasn’t yielding any results, so I expanded my search to second-hand dealer sites—only to realise that periodically checking each one was going to be tedious. That’s when I noticed something interesting: many of these websites used the same platform to manage their inventories. Recognising this, I reverse-engineered the platform’s structure and built an FME workspace that automated the search process for me. By integrating API calls and setting up periodic checks, I received real-time email alerts when matching cars were listed. In this presentation, I’ll walk through how I used FME to save hours of manual searching by creating a custom car-finding automation system. While FME can’t buy a car for you—yet—it can certainly help you find the one you’re after!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rbj6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbj6i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">VMware’s pricing changes have forced organizations to rethink their datacenter cost management strategies. While FinOps is commonly associated with cloud environments, the FinOps Foundation has recently expanded its framework to include Scopes—and Datacenter is now officially part of the equation. In this session, we’ll map the FinOps Framework to a VMware-based datacenter, focusing on cost visibility, optimization, and automation. You’ll learn how to track costs more effectively, rightsize workloads, optimize licensing, and drive efficiency—all without migrating to the cloud. We’ll also explore how to align IT teams, finance, and leadership around cost-aware decision-making for on-prem environments. If your VMware bill keeps increasing and you need a new approach to cost management, this session is for you!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rbr6i7d6:" popover="auto" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Have you ever struggled to read a tiny label on a medicine box or tried to navigate a confusing website? Now imagine if every learning experience felt that way—every single day.

For millions of people living with disabilities, poorly designed content isn’t just frustrating. It’s a barrier to growth. Inclusive learning is about fixing that. And today, AI is helping us build digital learning that’s smarter, kinder, and accessible to everyone.

Accessible learning increases engagement, retention, performance, and inclusivity for everyone. Inclusive design is simply better design.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rcb6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rcb6i7d6"></div><div Integrity: Synchronization between EAM and ArcGIS Utility Netw...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Improving Data Integrity: Synchronization between EAM and ArcGIS Utility Netw... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3rcj6i7d6:" popovertarget=":R3rcj6i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3rcj6i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R3rcj6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3rcj6i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SafeSoftware">Safe Software</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Utilities and water companies play a key role in the creation of clean drinking water. The creation and maintenance of clean drinking water is becoming a critical problem due to pollution and pressure on the environment. A lot of data is necessary to create clean drinking water. For fieldworkers, two types of data are key: Asset data in an asset management system (EAM for example) and Geographic data in a GIS (ArcGIS Utility Network ). Keeping this type of data up to date and in sync is a challenge for many organizations, leading to duplicating data and creating a bulk of extra attributes and data to keep everything in sync. Using FME, it is possible to synchronize Enterprise Asset Management (EAM) data with the ArcGIS Utility Network in real time. Changes (creation, modification, deletion) in ArcGIS Pro are relayed to EAM via FME, and vice versa. This ensures continuous synchronization of both systems without daily bulk updates, minimizes risks, and seamlessly integrates with ArcGIS Utility Network services. This presentation focuses on the use of FME at a Dutch water company, to create a sync between the asset management and GIS.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rcj6i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rcj6i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" Ltd.</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Artificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly changing the face of cybersecurity across the globe. In Nepal, the shift is already underway. Vice President of the Information Security Response Team Nepal (npCERT) and Information Security Consultant at One Cover Pvt. Ltd., Sudan Jha, recently presented an in-depth workshop on how AI can strengthen national security and digital defenses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rd36i7d6:" popover="auto" Framework.pdf</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:16 / 9;--index:0" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div November </a> 2017 - @billyleonard
10 Years of Targeted Credential Phishing
 </li></div><div><li>2. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#2">Threat Analysis Group
Billy </a> Leonard
Threat Analysis Group
 </li></div><div><li>3. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#3">Threat Analysis Group
But </a> first, ….
 </li></div><div><li>4. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#4">Threat Analysis Group
What </a> we don&#x27;t see in targeted phishing.
 </li></div><div><li>5. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#5">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>6. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#6">Threat Analysis Group
Targeted </a> attacks are all really advanced.
 </li></div><div><li>7. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#7">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>8. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#8">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>9. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#9">Threat Analysis Group
The </a> Early Days.
 </li></div><div><li>10. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#10">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>11. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#11">Threat Analysis Group
Source: </a> https://productforums.google.com/forum/?hl=en#!category-topic/gmail/reading-and-receiving-messages/EndXvDGLoe0
 </li></div><div><li>12. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#12">Threat Analysis Group
Source: </a> http://contagiodump.blogspot.com/2011/02/targeted-attacks-against-personal.html
 </li></div><div><li>13. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#13">Threat Analysis Group

 </li></div><div><li>14. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#14">Threat Analysis Group

 </a> </li></div><div><li>17. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#17">Threat Analysis Group
The </a> Middle Ages.
 </li></div><div><li>18. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#18">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>19. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#19">Threat Analysis Group
Password </a> Alert.
 </li></div><div><li>20. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#20">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>21. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#21">Threat Analysis Group

 </li></div><div><li>22. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#22">Threat Analysis Group

 </li></div><div><li>24. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#24">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>25. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#25">Threat Analysis Group </a> Source: https://techcrunch.com/2016/07/25/nist-declares-the-age-of-sms-based-2-factor-authentication-over/,

 </li></div><div><li>26. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#26">Threat Analysis Group

      // This script assumes the Osano script is synchronously loaded
      try {
        window.eventsToSend = window.eventsToSend || []
        if (window.Osano) {
          window.eventsToSend.push({
            name: "osano_loaded",
            timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
            value: JSON.stringify({
              time: performance?.now()
            })
          })
        }
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Failed to push Osano event:", error)

The report is based on scan data from over 85,000 applications assessed between April 2018 and March 2019. Key findings include: (1) Most security flaws are eventually fixed but fix times have remained consistent, (2) The likelihood of flaws being fixed decreases over time leading to growing \"security debt\", (3) Frequent scanning correlated with faster fix times and lower security debt indicating the benefits of DevSecOps practices. A few years ago, I faced this exact problem while searching for a particular vehicle in New Zealand. The local classified platform, Trade Me (similar to eBay), wasn’t yielding any results, so I expanded my search to second-hand dealer sites—only to realise that periodically checking each one was going to be tedious. That’s when I noticed something interesting: many of these websites used the same platform to manage their inventories. Recognising this, I reverse-engineered the platform’s structure and built an FME workspace that automated the search process for me. By integrating API calls and setting up periodic checks, I received real-time email alerts when matching cars were listed. In this presentation, I’ll walk through how I used FME to save hours of manual searching by creating a custom car-finding automation system. The creation and maintenance of clean drinking water is becoming a critical problem due to pollution and pressure on the environment. A lot of data is necessary to create clean drinking water. For fieldworkers, two types of data are key: Asset data in an asset management system (EAM for example) and Geographic data in a GIS (ArcGIS Utility Network ). Keeping this type of data up to date and in sync is a challenge for many organizations, leading to duplicating data and creating a bulk of extra attributes and data to keep everything in sync. Using FME, it is possible to synchronize Enterprise Asset Management (EAM) data with the ArcGIS Utility Network in real time. Changes (creation, modification, deletion) in ArcGIS Pro are relayed to EAM via FME, and vice versa. This ensures continuous synchronization of both systems without daily bulk updates, minimizes risks, and seamlessly integrates with ArcGIS Utility Network services. This presentation focuses on the use of FME at a Dutch water company, to create a sync between the asset management and GIS.","tags":["arcgis","asset management","fme flow"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/improving-data-integrity-synchronization-between-eam-and-arcgis-utility-network-at-a-dutch-utilities-company/280492941","userLogin":"SafeSoftware","userName":"Safe Software","viewCount":44},{"algorithmId":"4","displayTitle":"Coordinated Disclosure for ML - What's Different and What's the Same.pdf","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":23,"score":0,"slideshowId":"280701358","sourceName":"LATEST","strippedTitle":"coordinated-disclosure-for-ml-what-s-different-and-what-s-the-same-pdf","extension":"pdf","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/coordinateddisclosureforml-whatsdifferentandwhatsthesame-250618092710-29e65572-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Coordinated Disclosure for ML - What's Different and What's the Same","tags":["coordinated disclosure","ml"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/coordinated-disclosure-for-ml-what-s-different-and-what-s-the-same-pdf/280701358","userLogin":"cisoplatform7","userName":"Priyanka Aash","viewCount":22},{"algorithmId":"4","displayTitle":"Information Security Response Team Nepal_npCERT_Vice_President_Sudan_Jha.pdf","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":58,"score":0,"slideshowId":"280501515","sourceName":"LATEST","strippedTitle":"information-security-response-team-nepal_npcert_vice_president_sudan_jha-pdf","extension":"pdf","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/informationsecurityresponseteamnepalnpcertvicepresidentsudanjha-250613054744-b281fe4b-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Artificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly changing the face of cybersecurity across the globe.
